text:
Black, tan head, nice lacing, and decent head retention. Roast, mild licorice, dark fruit, mild alcohol, pine, and mild medicine notes. Medium bodied, malty front and hoppy finish, high roast & pine, and mild alcohol notes. High roast and hip notes, mildly astringent, and lingering hip bitterness. In summary, great nose, but flavor & palate miss mark due to astringent characters. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle: Poured a black with red edges and bubble head. Aroma is Coffee and malts. Taste is molasses, coffee, and malts.

(2016 bottle, 8% ABV) Pours black, with a large beige head and lot of sticky lacing. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee, with some citrus hoppiness. Taste is strong in roasted malts, chocolate and some notes of coffee, with a good balance of hops: citrus and pine. Quite bitter. Medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter finish. Excellent stout-ish black IPA.

Pours a dark black (a "stout" black) with mid-sized, creamy beige head. Aromas include chocolate, licorice, roasted grain, and a touch of bops. Flavors include chocolate, coffee, roasted grain, some hop-citrus and hop-pine. Fairly smooth beer with just a touch of bitterness in the finish/aftertaste.

Black pour with a thin beige head and lots of bands of striped lacing ..... aroma of roasted malts and cocoa with some light citrusy head .... taste is of roasted malts, rich chocolate, bitter citrusy hop bite and dry bitter rindy hops on the back end .... finishes abruptly with dry hops .... mouthfeel is soft yet has a nice dry bitter hop ... great balance .... very sessionable .... great brew
Pours very dark with a tan colored foamy head, immediate aromas of espresso and toasted nuts. Tastes of dark roast coffee, caramel and burnt sugar. Easy to drink, alcohol is not obvious. Great beer.

Pours a dark brown-black, thick and welcoming, offering up a respectable beige head with plenty of lace. Nose is surprisingly green and citric, more hop-forward than usual for an IPAs roasty cousin. Taste is primarily West Coast and bitter, large citrus-leaning hops giving up grapefruit and orange with a medicinal bitter background. Roasted malts add a mocha-tinged sweetness, with a slight hit of cherry popping up near the rear. Finishes semi-dry, the hops growing clingy and resinous, a mild note of unsweetened chocolate lurking on the periphery. Textures okay, a bit spiky but nothing too terrible. Solid Black IPA; always nice to see an example of the style that cant be simply summed up as a hoppy porter.

Draft @ the brewery. Pours a dark amber brown black color with a small off-white head. Has a slightly roasted malty caramel hoppy aroma. Slightly roasted malty piney hoppy bitter caramel flavor. Has a slightly roasted malty spicy caramel hoppy bitter finish.

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from Cigarette City. Appearance is almost opaque black--deep ruby red with light source directly behind--with nice sparkle at the edges of the glass, finger-plus width foamy light brown head with decent retention and fair lacing. Aroma is tropical fruit hops with roasted malt with molasses and anise. Taste is bittersweet roasted malts with fruity hops and late bitter. Palate is medium bodied with thick, foamy texture, lively carbonation and lightly bitter roasted/hoppy finish. Overall, good across the board.

Bottle, black beer huge, creamy almond colored head and thick lace. Aroma is toast and citrus. Taste is toast, coffee, orange, lemon peal, booze, but not hot, just, sorta, there...Palate is medium, carbonation average. Pair with kiwi murder mysteries and oatmeal cookies.
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of citrus, pine and chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter

From a 22floz bottle purchased in the St. Louis area for $4 and poured into a nonic glass. This must be the 2016 Fall edition as the bottle states an 8% ABV. Consumed 01.26.2017. There is not a freshness date, no bottling location (could be either CA or IL). It appears dark with a glistening tan head. Aromatics are of anise and molasses. Flavor is similar, although a piney hoppiness  and a bit of fig comes through. Textually it is mildly carbonated and the alcohol content is well masked. A pretty good black IPA typical in beery satisfaction to others Ive had in the style. This isnt a favored style for me. Yet, I enjoy the contradiction sometimes.

Bottled. Pours black. The palate is full body and thick. The taste is fruity hops. A lot of floral black hops. Not quite sure what makes a black IPA black but it has that black IPA taste and it big. Malty sweet backbone with a dry bitter aftertaste.

Tap. Brown color with tan head. Aroma is brown malts, cat piss hops. Taste is roasted malts, earthy hops. Bitter finish with more roastiness in the aftertaste. Medium carbonation. Still not my style, but this one is also not the best Black IPA either.

Lagunitas, Seattle. Very creamy off white head. Very dark brown Ale body. Creamy fresh sip. Nice CDA malt roast malts countered with full, lightly resinous pine hops. Touch of cream, not terribly complex. Solid drinker.
Draft. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Mild roast and black patent malts, with faint sweetness. A bit nondescript, with a quick finish. Fine.

Pours like a rootbeer float - dark & w/ a huge foamy tan head that leaves spotty lacing. The aroma is robust w/ piney hops. The flavor is mildly hoppy & surprisingly easy on the palate. The hop presence is there throughout but its just the right amount of bitterness. This is a very nice black ipa!
On draft at Mad Mex Lakeside. Poured near black with thin brown head. Sweet malt, roasty, hoppy/bitter finish.
Pours a very deep black. Dank earthy on the noise. Well balanced BIPA with beautiful Hop aromas and some rounded malt. A delicious beer that Ill certainly drink again!
Bomber. Light hoppy aroma. Jet black color with thick tan head, very nice lacing. Flavor has nice smooth bitterness, slight roastiness. Med bodied. Overall, a very nice black IPA!

22 oz bottle, PDT 10/11/16- Pours cola brown to almost black with a light tan head that retains nicely and cobwebby lacework. Aroma is before my nose even reaches the glass grapefruit, full on smell test exhibits chocolatey roasted malts, dark berry fruits, in particular i seem to be pulling blueberry out, some dank piney hops as well. The taste is roasty, chocolatey, more of a general hop bitterness, the finish imparts a black bitter coffee flavor, but overall very well balanced. Enjoyable for sure.

Dank and dark. One of the best Black IPAs I have had so far. Darkest of dark browns to almost black in color with a sandy colored head. The nose and palate are dominated by black licorice,subtle citrus, some earthy hops, a little plum and a light roast finish.
Bomber into a pint glass, pours almost black with a tan head with long lasting lacing. Very piney and grapefruit taste some clove and soy sauce. Not really my type of beer

Pours black with a long lasting cream colored head. Aroma is hoppy and nice but too overwhelming. Taste doesnt seem to be very bitter despite the IBUs. NightTime is well balanced between the hops and the malts. Nice! I like!

Beautiful, pours a thin black, beige head, splotchy cascading lace. Aroma is fresh hops, pine, toffee. Lots of roasted flavor for being fairly thin on the tongue. More pine resin, dark malts, notes of spice. Very easy to drink but full of flavor. Delicious.

Bottled. Pours deep brown close to black with a large tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, pine, orange zest and citrus. Sweet flavor that the up being more dry and bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. An excellent BIPA indeed. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2016 Wow, do I like a nice start. Fills my New Belgium chalice glass with an inky, almost black body. The head is a big strong chocolate with good effervescence. The first smell is great, nutmeg and hops, what a combo. What a surprise. And so is the taste. I detect oak, charcoal and molasses and still that hoppiness. Ends with a light bitterness. Hangs well. An adult taste, appreciated.

Bomber from a local liquor store in Vancouver area. Very dark with moderate tan head and sweet roasted nose. Sweet, fruity with dark roasted malts up front. A trace of bitterness. The best black ipa Ive ever tasted. 4

Bomber. I have not had a black IPA in ages, and I must say this is fantastic. Black with light brow head. Rich aroma of pine and soap. Crazy smooth. Pine and chocolate just melt together. I had a Storm King last weekend and I would say this is a close contender. I am totally digging this.

Bottle at the hotelroom in San Fransisco. Black beer with a nice lasting beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma, caramel, peach, oranges, some mango and grapes. Hoppy fruity flavor, caramel, chocolate, oranges, some pine. Quite well balanced and rather drinkable.

Pours a dark brown to black with a huge tan foamy head and lots of lacing. Nice piney hoppy aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture. Malty taste with a sharp hop bite. Fairly bitter finish and aftertaste. Ok but not very refreshing but still pretty enjoyable.

Bottle from City Swiggers, Manhattan, New York, USA. A black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Lots of aroma going on in this one, hoppy, roasty, malty, pine on the nose. Tastes similar, hoppy, roasty, malty, pine, hint of caramel. Great complexity in this black IPA. Beer this good makes you glad to be alive, wish Id brought more back with me across the North Atlantic.
Pretty good, but I get a clash of flavors between what I think is black patent malt & hops. Sharp. Its still pretty good butthe clash is obvious.
bottle. hands down the best black ipa ive had. just terrific balance while not letting the malt or hops dominate the other
Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine and Liquor. Nose is malty, spicy, plummy. Taste really nice of caramel, dark berries, plums and brown sugar. Nice creamy texture. Well done.
Really good floral aromas and great taste. Nice beer. Hides the alcohol well.
Pours a hazy medium brownish amber color. Aroma is lightly malty, hoppy, yeasty, with a touch of fruit. Flavor is a nice mixture of malts and fruits.

On tap at Twisted Jimmys (5/5/15). Fresh hoppy nose, floral and resiny. Smoky chocolate malt with some heavy aromas. Very fragrant. Dark black-brown opaque with light tan creamy lacing head. Medium-heavy body with medium carbonation. Starts moderately sweet with light tang, big hop flavor with chocolate and roasted malts. Molasses, coffee. Sweet tangy resin-like finish with roasted bitter after.
Roasted malt, slight fruit (grape) sweetness, with an underlying bitterness. Earthy tones. Dark chocolate color with a big tan foamy head. Nice lacing. Medium weight with mild carbonation.

This black IPA poured a nice black colour with a really foamy, tan coloured head. Scents include grass, spruce and roasty malts. First swig was nice and roasty with a good balance between hop and roast. Finish was medium bitter with nice grassy notes lingering with the burntness...

Too damn piney. Tastes like a dark IPA or something. But hey, I don't like traditional IPAs so there's that.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Rating #1275 - 07.10.2014 - On tap @revolutionyeg. Pours a California back alley black with a bubbly tan head. Aroma is a violent clash between toasted malt, and floral piney hops. Taste is extremely hoppy, tempered with a pleasant coffee, chocolate, burnt sugar sweetness that disguises any alcohol on the palate and rounds out the hoppy bitterness, and is beyond refreshing. Unreal hoppy black beauty.

Black hue, zero visibility with almost fully lasting frothy dark khaki head. Virtually no lacing. Aroma of citrus and dark roasted malts. Heavy citrus and coffee taste up front with more of a dark roasted malt finish. Slick mouth feel. I usually like most everything from Lagunitas but couldnt get into this one.
Big froathy pour that has smells of smoke and earth. Good hop taste with a deep dark malt and nice alcohol warmth.

Bottle. This pours as frothy as any beer Ive seen, deep black and piled with foam. This has an awesome "American" aroma of the outdoors. I cant say Im a big fan of this new "black IPA" thing, but this is ultimately a good beer. I think Id call it a hoppy porter ... gritty, a bit smoky, but topped with some west coast. (#6042, 10/9/2015)
Bottle. Pours a deep brown almost black colour with a beautiful medium tan head. Aroma is coffee, dark fruits, some chocolate, roasted malts. Taste to match. Very good.

2015 version from Stone in Asagaya. Pours a deep brown with a nice beige head that lasts throughout. Lots of aromas going on with milk chocolate, resin, coffee and dark fruit all noticeable. Great carbonation with a slightly sticky mouthfeel. The chocolate really comes out in the finish. Good bitterness that lingers.

Pitch black pour with a tight tan head. Very piney aroma with white grapefruit, roasted malts and a hint of smokiness. Flavor matches the aroma perfectly with a bitter sweet chocolate ending. Medium plus bodied with smooth carbonation

Probada en Blind Tiger, Nueva York. Esta birra esta muy piola. Va como piña para lo que sea.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Roasty, but crisp. Hints of coffee and nuts, earthy with a nice balance of hops. Bitterness is kept to a minimum.
Pitch black. Smells like black ipa. Mix of hops and malt. Had six pack from Holmes. Good.
On draft. Black with one finger beige head. Roasted malt and citrus on the taste. Creamy palate. Really nice.

Bottle. Dark brown, nearly black pour with a thick beige head. Fairly mild aroma, some roasty malts and bright citrus showing through, a bit of creamy chocolate. Taste is big bright citrus with a crisp bitter edge, but supported by rich, roasty malt, fairly thick texture and a bit of a creamy chocolate finish. More fruity as it warms. A really nice black IPA with a lot of body and a good balance.

Bottle.

Pours nearly black with a beige head. 

Aromas of pine and grapefruit.

Flavor of pine, citrus, mainly grapefruit, and some light chocolate or coffee.

On tap at The Ginger Man, NY. An almost black one, topped by a finger-thick, dense, light beige head. The aroma is lightly roasted, with pine cones, orange zest and resins. Its full-bodied and semi-dry with a nice carbonation level and flavors of light roasted malts, zest and pine cones and a nice bitterness. Lightly roasted hop dominated finish. Quite lovely this one, more focused on the hops than the malts, which is the way I like it. 150624

Bottle. Pours black with a foamy beige head. Aroma of pine, citrus and grapefruit. Flavor of dark malts, pine, roast, citrus fruit, grapefruit and some light chocolate. Medium body, soft carbonation, dry finish.

Aroma: melasa, pine and resin, roasted notes.
Appearance: black color and beige thinhead.
Taste: high bitterness (herbs abd resin), herbal notes, slightly roasted, melasa, bitter chocolate, quite dry.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, bitter finish.
Overall: Interesting variation on Black IPA, nice pine bitterness.

This is excellent, probably the best black ipa I have had. Aroma is full of chocolate and roasty malts but theres a hoppiness that cuts throught and you get a nice blast of citrus pine. Taste is really really good. You get the best aspects of a nice heavy chewy stout but theres a huge bitterness from the ipa side of the beer. Its citrusy and tropical and meshes perfectly with the stout. I really enjoyed this beer, it was a nice breath of fresh air for me. Its very different but executed well and like I said, the best black ipa Ive had so far.
Hops fill my nose with a malty sweet underlying body in this clear super deep red brew. The taste is hoppy sweet with a hint of licorice it seems. It's medium bodied and a decent carb.

Pours black with a khaki head. Head retention is great. AROMA: hop spice, pine, caramel, herbs, very slight chocolate and malty. TASTE: hop spice/bitter, bittersweet citrus, caramel, malty, coffee, chocolate, herbs, alcohol, soy sauce, spice, dark fruit, clove and slight molasses. AFTER TASTE: hop bitterness, chocolate bitterness, malt and spices with a rich slightly thick finish.

Bottle - Pours dark with a fairly big, frothy head that left some lacing. Great aromas of pineapple, mango, and caramel. Notes of chocolate with citrus IPA flavors and a warming finish. The kind of beer I like.

Draught @ The Ginger Man, New York, NY
Pours almost black with a beige head. Aroma has notes of malt, citrus, grape and pine. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long slightly roasted, chocolate, citrus, grape and pine finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

12oz bottle pour to mug. Sour spiced hops with a dry bitterness. Sweet syrupy malts are thicker than expected. The flavor combo comes off as a bit of a mismatch though still easily drinkable if you dont mind something odd.

12oz bottle to cervoise. Pours black with big creamy tan head. Aroma of baking chocolate, rubber, raisins and anise. Taste is big baking chocolate, dark malts, some raisins, licorice and toffee. Good bitterness. Finish is not long-lasting. Decent carb for such a dark beer. Cant help but tasting rubber...it is off-putting.
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is earthy, pine and a touch or roast. Taste is moderate bitters with a drying finish. Medium bodied with well hidden alcohol.

Black-brown body with a cola head. Nice medley of forestry PNW hops--pine, evergreen--and with a clean roastiness. Juicy flavors with a bit of candi sweetness, but full of PNW hop nectar. Sweet, debittered roasty and hoppy finish. A solid CDA.

Strong pine and cut grass aroma from bottle before pour. Dark stout like pour. Tan creamy head. Good lacing through out glass. Flavor not as strong as the aroma. Nice balance of malt and hops. Solid experience.

Somewhat piney hop aroma. Beautiful ebony color with a towering tan head that lasts forever. Sweet molasses flavor up front. Notes of toffee, and bitter chocolate. Bitterness cuts in slowly. Bitter chocolate mixed with piney hop bitterness that is fairly mellow. Finish is a piney resin mixed with traces of dark chocolate. Slick mouth feel with some good amount of carbonation for the style.

Mildly soapy, has a great malt and bitter balance. Wild taste of hoppy taste, it's great flavor make for a special beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours as black as any stout with a lot of creamy head. The aroma is charcoal and some grassy hops. The flavor adds a really rich, burnt malt with a dense hop finish. Its not quite as good as Stones Self Righteous or Firestone Walkers Wooky Jack, but its a solid black IPA. Well worth it at the reasonable price.

Hoppy with that lagunitas flavor that is hard to pin down. Smells like citrus and pours dark with a tan head. Had out of a bottle at Ahmad's. Decent beer. Strong alcohol. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Totally dark with a large khaki colored head and very good lacing. Resinous hop aroma touched with some roastiness and dark fruit. Taste turns a bit more citrus but the roast is still there to maintain balance. A happy marriage in the aftertaste. Medium-to-full bodied, nicely carbonated mouthfeel leading to a lingering finish.

HAHA LET ME TELL YOU ABOUT NITE TIME!!! SO MY BUDDIE STEVE INVITE ME OFF TO HIS CONDOMANIEUM COMPLAX ON SOME DRINK. HE DOES NOT DO A PLINY (MY TOP FAVORITE OF BEER) BUT HE SAYS HE HAVE SOME GOOD STUF THERE WE TRY. HE PULL ON LAGUNITA HOOCH MAKER NITE TIME BEER AND I NEARED FAINT. I HATE LAGUNITA HOOCH ;THEY WENT TOO BE RUSHAN RIVER BUT THERE NOT! ANY WAYS - STEVE HAVE ME TWO SIP THIS BEER AND THAN THINGS START TO DETEAREORATE. HE CALL ME AND BAD NAME AND TELL ME BUSH WOULD GET RIDE OF ME AND I GET SCARE. HE START TALK FOR PISTOLS AND SHOOTING RANGE TO TRY ME MAKE GOOD (I HAVE GUN] BUT HE GETS DARKER AND I FEELS FOR MY HOLE LIFE IN A FLASHING. The aroma is hops, a little floral, grass, spruce. Pours a dark brown with big tan head, mostly diminishing with excellent lacing. The taste is bitter. The body is medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish long and bitter. Very Good!

This is a solid beer. Hops and citris on the nose, first taste is hops, pine, much like an IPA but the coffee roast taste is stronger and gives this beer a good balance. I bought six of these and they may not last long.
On tap. Tan-mahogany. A-citrus, hint of roast. As it warms the roast comes out. T-roasty dk malt, 2nd sweet/juicy citrus/pine hops.
Grassy hop aroma. Coffee beans, rich roasted malt, brown sugar, green hop, spice, lingering espresso finish. Nose is not my thing but a great bouquet of flavors, tasty black ipa.
Poured from a bottle. Delicious beer, well deserving of the high marks. Huge head. Dark caramel appearance. Rich, bold aroma, bite on the c swallow, chocolate and code coffee. Good beer.
Bottle to pint. 1 finger of head. Caramel chocolate aroma. Sweet maltiness with a dry finish.
33 cl bottle thanks to k0mpsa. Beautiful color, pitch black with small diminishing head. Hoppy, banana peel and fruity nose. Nice hoppy bitter body with lenghty flavors. Really nice.
Bottle. Many thanks to Shawn Burns! Black color, tanned head. Aroma has roasty notes, licorice, some hoppy notes. Nice roasty body, coffee, hoppy notes on the back.

Pours a clear dark brown body under a large frothy light brown head that left lots of sticky lace. The aroma is slanted towards the IPA realm, but theres some nice chocolate and roasty malt under all those hops too. The flavor is more Porter-like though, with chocolate, coffee, and lightly roasty maltiness up front. The finish features some piney hops to balance the malt. Lingering burnt caramel and piney hops. Light up medium bodied, rather smooth on the palate, with soft gentle carbonation. One of my personal favorites from Lagunitas.

Pours a deep brown almost black color. Aroma of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Taste is similar to the aroma, with rich flavor, even some coffee mixed in. A slight bitterness after the swallow, with dark malt flavors coating the palate.

[Bottle] Deep brown hue borders on black. Tan foam on top. Aromas of sticky hops, brown sugar, anise and cocoa. Flavors are centered on a sharp resinous hop bitterness blended with sticky malts, molasses, tobacco, milder coffee flavors and some earth. Medium bodied. Lively carbonation. More roast comes out as the bitterness fades. Still pretty drinkable despite the robust nature of the beer.

Dark brown/black with tan head. Slight onion, citrus aroma. Very pleasant on the palate. Most black IPAs seem to have to much roast flavor but not this one. I pick up raisin and licorice notes. Will seek out again.
Pours a solid black color, but has very nice lacing. Also has a nice creamy head and smells mildly of pine. Has a nice malty, hoppy taste and is a nice beer.

Pours a black from a bottle, a quick glance would indicate a stout or very dark porter, with a nice dark khaki head. Piney hops attack the nose while tender chocolate malts gently wrestle in the background. Flavor is like drinking an unsweetened can of Moxie through a straw made out of leather. Bitterness assails you throughout like an American Gladiator, knocking you slightly off-balance just like the overall mouthfeel. Okay, this review is a little over the top, but all in all it is a good beer.

Aroma is Lagunitas citrusy hops with a sweet malty background, hint of molasses. Appearance is nearly black with a frothy tan head. Taste is hop bitterness and flavor forward, large malt present as well, roast is present but easily confused with the high IBUs. Palate is medium full. Crisp and clean but with big malt. Overall a very nice beer. Probably my favorite of this style, which I typically do not enjoy. That said... if you closed your eyes you might think this was a malty IPA, roast is not too pronounced.
Looks and tastes like a roasted porter. Smells like an IPA. Quite a hybrid. Not bad.

(bottle - 12 oz - 2015 vintage) Dark brown pour with a puffy tan head. Piney and roasty aroma. Lots of pine and roasted malt and chocolate in the flavor with a dry and bitter finish. Lingering resin aftertaste.

Bottle poured a black hue w/ large frothy tan head and big sticky lacing. Bold piney aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a bold bitter finish. Tastes are piney hop, coffee, light melon and light grass. Medium bodied.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From cask - Poured a dark black with minimal head. Has some apricots and berries on the nose. Taste - Thin to medium mouth feel. The apricots come through and it finishes clean and fairly malty with a hint of star anise. Not great but not horrible. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured black with nice tan head. Nice hoppy aroma. With the hops forward followed by a nice roasted malt character. Not to bitter that you would expect. Throw on some David Gray and relax.

Bottle (12oz) from stateline. Poured into a snifter big ole rocky head that sticks around, black in color. Lacing left all over the glass. Nose of roasted malts and fresh hops. Reminds me of a porter... nose is chalky/ashy. Taste is initially lots of roasted malts, followed by a nice hop presence but not over whelming or IPA like. Dry and easy drink. Overall nice black IPA even though I wish they didnt call it that. Pairs well with Bob Seger night moves or Jimis night bird flying!
Pours black with tan head and lots of chunks at the bottom. Smells pint, roasty and plums. Tastes bitter from the hops then a coffee and roasty after taste. Best black IPA i've had.
12 oz bottle from Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. One to savor, like a late night brandy. Truly a unique experience that shouldnt be missed.

Pours black with a small head. Smells of bread an hops - spruce
Taste is bitter and moderately sweet, hoppy but balanced.

Poured black with really nice tan head. Nice hoppy aroma. With the initial taste, I picked up the hops first followed by a nice roasted malt character. Did not seem to be as bitter as you would expect from the listed IBUs making for a nicely balanced beer.
Dark brown pour with a small 1 finger brow head. Taste is of dark rotated malts followed by the bittering hops.

2015 bottle at home. Pours black, white foamy head. Nice contrast between beer and foam. Aroma is pine, floral hops, a bit of roasted malts. Nice IPA smell. Taste is piney, earthy hops, roast malts, a bit of cracker and light coffee notes. Moderate bitterness. Good IPA that had me questioning if it was actually as black as it is. Balanced, great example of this style. Grab one.
Black beer. Space heavier roast than most of its style and sweeter to familiar dry hot profile common to so many of the style. good.
7.11.2014. Aroma has pine, earthy hops, resin. Hoppy piny taste, slight roast, resin, plum.

Tropical fruits on the nose. The same applies to the taste and even a little sweet. Heavy bitterness that fills the mouth forever. Lovely beer but maybe a little too bitter. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Dark and hoppy in the aftertaste, weirdly malty on the front end. Pours nice, but not my style. Top quality beer, though, as everything from Lagunitas seems to be. I wouldnt drink more than two of these at any setting. The hop aftertaste is almost overwhelming, and it seems to sit on the tongue forever.
Black pour, brown head. Roasty aroma with notes of dank, resinous hops. Flavor is big and roasty, dank, sharp, hoppy and boozy.

Very dark brown, almost black with a large tan head. A great black IPA. Heavy on the hops with an excellent roasty taste. This beer is well balanced, has a pretty full body and nice hints of chocolate and coffee.

Beer club 22oz. bottle. Pours a dark mahogany with a very enticing medium tan head. Roasted malt aroma carries thru with coffee and maybe a little carmel to taste. Didn't seem to be a 8% alc. beer. Very good, although 65 is pushing my IBU tolerance.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Has. DBIPA. Holy crap, this is like the opposite of Pepsi clear. Abuse of hops (not a bad thing) in all stages of additions). An interesting element brought by the darkness, but still a rough hop bomb. Very butter. Maybe that is needed to balance the burnt malt, otherwise, Lag knows better. Some tops the scale, tho all hop. BDIPA is still in infancy, so who knows. If this was amber, it would be a text book generic over hop DIPA. But as a BDIPA, this is great
Draught @ NYC Craft Beer Festival. Hazy dark brown with very small foamy beige head, floral hops aroma, medium carbonation, citrus taste, long bitter finish with lemon peel aftertaste. Quite nice!

Bottle. Poured an almost black color with a small tan head. Aroma was light pine needle notes, that roasty note that comes through only on black IPAs... Pretty tasty black IPA, for price point its pretty good.

4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey. Black with light tan head. Aromas of pine and freshly picked pine needles, floral, roast. Tastes of pine, floral, roast, dark chocolate. Medium body with a dry finish.

On tap at Frisco Taphouse and Brewery in Columbia, MD. 

Opaque, near black with a nice tan head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of grapefruit, caramel, light pine and a hint of roasted malt. 

Taste of prunes, grapefruit, roasted malt, mild chocolate, pine and caramel. 

Medium/full body and medium/low carbonization with a smooth mouthfeel.

An excellent India black ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours black with tan head and some lacing. Nose is hops with some soy sauce. Taste is same with a little chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel. I'm not a big black IPA fan but this is pretty good.

From a 12 oz poured in a small glass. Flavor is hop forward but malty and roasted malt. However, no really dark coffee-type flavors come through. Not bad. Not really my cup of tea, but Its acceptable.

Oh my word. Ive always said that Lagunitas is one of the most reliable brewers in the world--they must "hit" with a higher percentage of releases than anyone--and thats the case even though I am not a hop-head. The way they use hops and balance them is more compelling than when hops are in the hands of anyone else. This was another case in point. The hops were so fresh, so vibrant, and so multifaceted, but the impact in the finish was so pleasant and balanced by the malty sweetness...it was magnificent. High alcohol didnt affect the flavor. Really excellent. Kudos, Lagunitas! Bottle.
Poured very dark with a huge head. In the mouth it is a ton of hops, but not overt at all.
12 oz bottle. Aroma: malty and roasty, with hints of hay and coffee. Taste/Palate: starts sweet and creamy; finishes crisp, bitter, and astringent.
Poured from a 12. Aroma is very piney and grassy. Flavor is very hoppy and grassy. Finish is a great bitter hoppy finish with a slightly sweet flavor left over.

Bottle (7.9%) from Fred Meyer. Black in appearance upon pouring. Nose is dominated by some grapefruit bitterness. The roast is only slightly noticeable. Very hoppy with some grapefruit and tropical notes. Some roastiness. The roast just seems to blend in with the hop flavor. Solid job on getting the roast and bitterness to meld so well.

A very dark brown, nearly black pour with a large, long-lasting light caramel colored head. Robust, resinous hop nose. Somewhat thick for the style. Good carbonation. Good balance in spite of it being aggressively hopped.

By far the least hoppy/bitter Lagunitas, probably only because it actually has some balance instead of blasting your bitter tastebuds. A nice Black IPA, I guess its seasonal/limited but I would actually like to see this one out year-round.

A dark brown, quite opaque color with a frothy cream colored head. A mild fruity/hoppy aroma. The taste has a mild chicory overtone. A mild hoppy aftertaste.

Bottle. Citrus and yeasty aroma, with sweet dark fruit notes. Dark brown with a thick rocky tan head. Citrus, immediately undercut by dark fruit, some chocolate, berries (especially blueberries), and a touch of coffee. Medium body. Tasty and rich in fruit flavors. Very good.

Bottle. Pours deep black, big tan head. Some retention/good lace. Aroma of grassy/pine/resin hops, roast, coffee, chocolate. Taste is bitter, pine, resin, roast, iced coffee. Palate is average carbonation, slick, bitter finish.

Aroma: grass, herbs, floral, 
Appearance: black, full head
Taste; very bitter, light sweetness, 
Palate: full body, thick feel, lively, bitter,

Bottle. Perfectly black with a lightly yellowish khaki head. Nose of anise, toffee, and coffee. Walnuts were also present. The taste was strongly roasted coffee with some walnuts. Green beans are also present along with some umami character. A decent effort, but a little off putting the almost meaty finish. An overall decent sipper.

Black. Great, lasting, frothy beige head. Awesome fresh hoppy aroma. Pine and grapefruit. Smooth medium body. A little oily. Flavor is Loaded with hops as well. Moderate plus bitterness. No harshness. Really easy going dark malts. Definitely true to the spirit of the black IPA. Excellent.
super dark color, decent head, and super hoppy aroma. Rich, sweet, but bright and fairly refreshing.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a big pillowy tan head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is acidic roast chocolate malt with fruity piney hops and a little smoke.

The flavor is sweet roasted acidic chocolate malts with some fruity piney hops and a bit of an ashy bitter finish. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, Im liking this years version better than last year. Less sweet with more going on.

Midnight with one finger dark tan head. Strong floral hop character in the aroma. If I had my eyes closed I would think I was drinking a normal ipa. No noticeable dark malt flavors at all. The hop flavor is somewhat tangy.

12oz. bottle poured into a shaker- poured non transparent solid black color when held to a light source. 3mm off tan head formed and tried its best to lace upon the vessel. Aroma of resin, grapefruit, pine, and caramel that needed about 30 more seconds of cooking to break down the sugars. Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, hops are very forward while the malt stays in the background, caramel and hops in the middle, finish is just somewhat acidic instead of it being an acid bomb in your mouth. Okay.

Undated 12 oz. bottle {7.9% ABV, 71 IBU, 1.075 OG} aggressively poured into an IPA glass. Very dark, very black brew - 2 finger dense nougat-like caramel-brown head. Dank cedar-grapefruit citrus-y hops hit the nose first. As it warms, toffee, earthy roasted malts become more prevalent. Heavily carbonated, foamy - silky sweet espresso with tastes of rye, hay, & oatmeal are subtle to resinous finishing hops. Roasted malt aftertaste. Outstanding Black (double?) IPA.

Best black IPA Ive ever had, hands down. Pours black. Creamy chocolate head, super thick lacing, looks amazing. Aroma of hoppy goodness, pine, oats, dark malts, resin, beautiful dark fruit cascades. Taste of brilliant dark hops, clear and distinctive mouth feel leaves me in awe, doesnt drink like a dark IPA, more like a freshly glazed hopped up black pilsner, just wonderful. Packs a punch with the 7.9, but really, it only compliments the whole picture. Lagunitas does not make a bad beer. This one is exceptional

Opaque black. Nice lace, short creamy head. Hoppy aroma of bright sweet fruit, toasted marshmello with sweet pastry. Soft smooth slick malt, creamy, chocolate, light roast more on the finish,hops with citrus, fruit, all the way through. Want to say umami. Bitter sweet but more sweet, somewhat syrupy, but huge Big pine bitter to balance with the roast. Lagunitas is not shy about hops. Has some salty/ astringency in finish. Gets ashy and astringent as it warms in finish. Bitter linger and salty linger.

Black pour with a tall, creamy, then chunky tan head. Aroma is dark caramel, dank hops, citrus, passion fruit heavy tropical notes, a hint of smoke an odd onion-like note, a touch of iodine and some odd salty mushroom notes. Bottle from six pack aroma. Big grapefruit hop nose, tropical fruit, sweet melon, dark sweet jams (blackberry?), little to no roast. Flavor of beef jerky, salt, umami notes. Bitter hop notes. Overly boozy, touches of soy sauce on the back end.

Pours black color with a creamy Nitro-like head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and hops. Nice. Flavor is lots of roasted malts, chocolate, some hops in the middle. And a hoppy bitter finish. Great black IPA.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with tall, long lasting, fluffy beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is of citrusy hops, tropical fruit and toasted malt. Body is full and tangy. Citrusy hops dominate the palate while dark fruit, toasted malt and coffee linger in the background. Finish is long, and dry. Im not a fan of the style, but this is one tasty brew.

Motor oil black pour, creamy tan head with decent lace. Nose is fresh pine. Bitter. Middle is spruce sap, earth, dark malt, and a hint of chocolate. finish is piney, bitter, and long. Very well hidden ABV, just part of the profile.

12 oz bottle pours black with a light brown head. A minimally hoppy aroma, with burnt coffee or cocoa and wheat. Some very interesting flavors. This brew is a bit thin, soft carbonation but it finishes slowly. I wasnt sure at first, but it grew on me. Its solid.
Dark pour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and citrusy hops. Inviting aroma. Citrusy hops upfront with a solid roasted malt backbone. Great lacing shown on each sip taken.
Aroma of pine, hops, some citrus, taste is very hoppy, lots of pine, citrus, very drinkable, very good!
Excellent. Not generally a favorite style of mine, but this is somewhere between an ipa and a porter, good hop wallop with a roast malt backbone. Tasty and creamy.

Poured up black with a decent tan head. Smells of a whole lot of pine hops. This smells pretty good for an IPA but this is black and that is when I realize what I got in my glass. Another damn black IPA. I hate black IPAs. Just saw this sitting on the shelf and assumed it would be something like a stout or a porter but no it was massively hopped for a stout gone wrong or an IPA that is using the wrong malts. Wish I had found this as a sample cause now I have 5 more of these to do something with.

12oz bottle. Pours black and opaque with no lacing and asmall-medium head. Nice aroma, medium and piney. Taste is bitter-hoppy with not a real malt undertone to balance it. Errs too much on the IPA side, not really that good, I dont think. I know everyone else seems to like it, but I dont think so.

Bottle, shared by me, in my dining room, just now.
Pours almost black with dark brown hues when held up to light. The head is big and leaves nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is just wonderfully bright and hoppy. This is one where blindfolded I could never tell its black IPA. Thats not to mention that there is practically zero booziness to the bouquet for a beer pushing 9% abv. Its got all sorts of citrus zest & fresh grapefruit with a little muskmelon and dank hop character. Geeze man, this smells so nice. 

The flavor follows suit with the grapefruit & citrus zest. There is a little more pineyness in the flavor & a pretty nice smack of hop bitterness. The light roasty malt presence is defiantly noticeable, but not in an especially bad way, similarly is the case with the booze, you can tell its strong but at no point does the alcohol play an interfering role with the other flavors. 

The palate is sharp at first but finishes very smoothly. There is a bit of lingering bitterness in the finish that leaves the tongue wanting for more. 

Its just very good beer, maybe the best one Ive had from Lagunitas.

Draft at SB. Pours an opaque near-black with a dense and creamy tan head that doesn’t stick around forever. Big tangy piney nose with some bright fresh-cut wood on the nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Dark woody roasty sweet caramel on the mid palate with big piney overtones on the mid palate. Great marriage of dark roasty malts and bright shining hops. Long crisp resiny finish. Really good.

Aroma: The aroma is pine and roast, some coffee notes, and a bit of citrus as well

Not sure how Im missed out on rating this one in the past, but this is just a really good, enjoyable Black IPA. I for sure couldnt see any reason to give it lower than a 4.0, and in fact, I had to go higher. Especially the palate. This is a great beer.

Draft at SB. Pours an opaque near-black with a dense and creamy tan head that doesnt stick around forever. Big tangy piney nose with some bright fresh-cut wood on the nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Dark woody roasty sweet caramel on the mid palate with big piney overtones on the mid palate. Great marriage of dark roasty malts and bright shining hops. Black with a dusty tan, 1.5-inch, foamy head that fades at a moderate-slow rate. Passion fruit hits me immediately from a foot away. Yum! Up close: more passion fruit, pineapple, lychee, pear, some mango and orange. Wow. Just a hint of coffee and a touch of apple tart. Flavor is lychee, pineapple, dark-roasted candied almonds lightly spiced and sugary, passion fruit, kettle corn. Light touch of short-lived bitterness in the finish. Wow!! Body is medium-medium-light, starchy, lightly oily, semi-creamy, medium-fine carbonation with moderate smooth burn. Overall: one hell of a black IPA.

Pours a black with a full, smooth and creamy looking tan head that settles very slowly. A pleasing aroma has grapefruit, pine, earthy malts, chocolate, a bit of smokiness, and resin. The taste is similar to the aroma. Its bitter and earthy, with grapefruit, pine, and smoke standing out most here. These are complimented by lesser amounts of chocolate, some nuts, coffee, and roasted malt. Aftertaste is an earthy pine flavor. This is full bodied, with a thicker texture, and average in carbonation. This is a very good offering in this style. There is quite a bit going on here and a lot to enjoy.

This beer pours a dark black with some ruby when held up to light. There was a thick head that is tan and left plenty of lacing around the glass. The aroma is citrus, pine, hops, some sweetness, and grassy. The taste is dark roasted malts, lots of citrus, and some pine. There is quite a bit of hop bitterness in there as well but the alcohol is hidden for being a 8%. The drinkability on this beer is very high and the mouthfeel is on the medium to thick side.
Starts out looking like a stout but the smell and taste goes the other way. This has a lot of good IPA qualities and is close to 8%. Another quality offering by Lagunitas.

Flavors of roasted nut malt and dark chocolate combine with a distinct piney and green vegetable note. A warm, bread nuance lingers with vegetal hops. Warming, not quite my style of Black IPA, but I can appreciate it.

Pours very dark brown with an immense head really a great pour. The strong alcohol is well hidden with a robust malt flavor hints of chocolate. really well made brew perhaps the best I have had from Lagunitas. I understand the other high marks.
robust nutty flavors. very dark amber with a lasting tan head. wonderful mouth feel.
Big nose. Orange rind, tropical hops. Medium roast coffee beans, biscuit malts balanced well with tropical hops and pine. Some caramel sweetness with an earthy finish mixes nice with the hops.
Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Pours a warm cola color. Aromas of sweet hops. Taste is a lovely blend of slight saltiness, sweet, and bitter. As wonderful as the DayTime.
Bottle thanks to Tony. Poured very dark brown black with thick beige head. Aroma of resin dank hop lil roast. Light carb med bod. Resin bitter taste. Ok

Poured with limited head, yet strong lacing. Brown coffee coloration to the head. Aroma of hops and flavors not common with a darker beer like this. Tara off with clear hop notes, although not citrusy. Transitions to a clean malty finish with coffee and chocolate notes, and the faint sweetness from hops. A nice job.

On tap at brewery with lamont brian sara takes Kelly Oris cho... nice pile of joy..would do again

Pours black with tan head, porter-like. But smells for all the world like a west coast IPA: resin, lime, pine. Taste is big, and great, though frankly it can get a bit muddled with so many flavors: citrus, pine, coffee, burnt caramel, moderate sweetness. Quite nice.

M: Creamy smooth.

O: This is a good CDA. There has not been a Lagunitas beer that I havent liked.

22 oz bottle poured near black with a large, frothy tan head that had excellent retention and left lots of sticky lacing on the glass. 

Aroma: a substantial hhop load is immediately apparent, and this smells much more like an IPA than a Black Ale. 

Flavor: nice mix of hops and dark roasted grains, with a moderate bitterness that does not build in the finish or aftertaste.

O: with milder hop flavor than most Amer. Black IPAs, this is more of a Black APA.
Roasty. Dark. Fruit. Expresso color. Medium to heavy palate. Very good black IPA. Top three black IPA for me - Odell Mountain Standard, Lagunitas Nighttime Ale, and Firestome Walker Wookey Jack.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks DSG. Pours brown with a beige head, aroma of grapefruit, tangerine, roasted, flavor is bitter, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and tangerine, medium bodied.

Good sized light brown head of medium sized bubbles. Hoppy and fruity aroma with sweet tarts, floral hops, raisins and some dark malts. Color is a very dark crimson brown. Soft and smooth mouthfeel with plenty of hops bitterness to go around. Little bit of mint, roasted grains, raisins again and some cough syrup. Very strong lingering malts with a noticable alcohol presence. Finishes sticky and malty with a bit of bitterness. I didnt realize that this was a black IPA otherwise I would have drank it sooner. Still a solid brew though.
Black, golden brown lace. Nice citric hop aromatics. Fine roast , light bready malt base. Broad hoppiness- grassy, citric pinelike. Mellow mouthfeel. Long hoppy tail. Very pleasant.

Dark brown in the glass with an off-white head. Aroma is nutty, some cocoa, with a light bitterness. Really nice, creamy beer, that pairs unsweetened chocolate with light resinous hop bitterness. Much more coherent than some other examples of this style. Tasty bottle, I would definitely pick this up again.

Very dark pour, soft light brown head. Strong roasted coffee aroma, very nice bitterness on the tongue, maybe some licorice behind the unsweetened chocolate and a pleasant acidity. Looks like it would be sweet and heavy, isnt either. Another interesting Lagunitas brew. I would definitely pick this up again.
Poured from bomber...pour is black with nice thick head....nose is roasted caramel and hops...taste is same...really good stuff...

Poured from bomber into some weird teardrop glass. Lots of thick head. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavor is not as intense as some other black IPAs I've had. For the most part, it is well balanced and enjoyable.
Black color, big beige head. Aroma of pine and roasted caramel. Balanced taste of dark , roasted malt and hops. Decent bitterness . Roasted and hoppy aftertaste. Perfect hidden alcohol.

I finally got around to opening this bomber Dan gave me for fathers day. Pours black with a Huge, frothy, rough bubbled, lacy light brown head. Grapefruit, pine, chocolate aroma. Flavor is cream, rich chocolate malt/fudge, pine and bitter hops. Creamy and smooth. A tiny bit of warmth from the alcohol. This is an outstanding BIPA.

Thanksgiving 11-27-14 poured from bomber. Dark brown body, light brown head reduces to the rim. Nice malty dark ale, straight forward. Tastes like a stout, NOT a CDA (black IPA) with no hop character. 4 in category; 8.5 bd, 7 kevmar, 8 dad

Bottle. Moderate to heavy roasted and caramel for the malt, Moderate to heavy pine for the hops, light leather for the yeast, with tar, toffee and licorice in the background. head is small, frothy, light beige with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, slick with a lively to fizzy carbonation. Nice balance betwen the malt and hops in this tasty Black IPA.
Rating the day after: Nice balanced beer. Pours dark and does not taste like an 8.2% beer. Will definitely be buying again.

Bomber. Clear deep dark ruby hued brown, solid tan froth settles and lasts. Piney citrus dark roast aroma. Taste is juicy fruity citrus hops well balanced with smooth darker malts, some earthy herbal pine notes, faint hints of black licorice and chocolate, some spiciness. Softer carbonation, medium-full bodied, well hopped. Long bittersweet finish. Well done. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)
Complex aroma of coffee, chocolate and a hint of anise. Dark brown color with a small tan well laced head. Creamy feel with a chocolate and coffee taste. A delicious coffee finish.
Terrific beer. Gorgeous lacing and wonderful hoppiness. I dont recall it being quite so tasty in a bottle. Hard to believe its abv is 8.6

Rated on 7-27-2014. This bottled beer forms a medium sized smooth tan head, opaque dark brown body and a fair amount of lacing. The aroma is citrus, pine, perfume, and herbal hops. The flavor is moderate bitterness, pine, citrus, and herbal hops. The mouthfeel is moderate carbonation and this beer is light-medium bodied. Overall, this beer is quaffable. However, I find it to be too bitter tasting for my liking. It has a lingering bitter aftertaste that is not too offensive.

Aroma has salty licorice and some cocoa. Flavour has salty licorice, deep roasted tones, tobacco and hints of ash. Also some tea(!). A bit too salty and thin but nice anyway.

65 cl bottle @ ISKTR 2014.
Pours dark red color with a small head. Lots of hops here even though its not fresh. resinous, pine and caramel too. Bitter fruity palate, caramel, resin, some wooden notes too. Might contain some house flavor. Nice.

Bottle @ home, tfs vaiz! Aroma is fruity hops, some roast and caramel. Flavour is quite bitter of hops and roast, some pine and caramel. Nice.

A dark amber in the body with a huge beige head and tons of lacing on the glass. The aroma is hop laden with a good balance of roasted malt notes. [My bottle (660ml) shared with HogTownHarry, jercraigs & mabel] Pours a dark golden-brown with a large semi-lasting frothy beige head and lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma and flavour of leafy hops, roasted malt and thats it, simple but pleasant enough. Alcohol is well hidden. Average to medium bodied. Pretty good.

2014-10-09. Very dark mahogany brown body with a nice foamy head. 3+ Aroma of mild green hops and light roast. Flavour is mildly bitter, good leafy green hops throughout. Moderate dark malt and light roast. Lingering fruity green hops. Smooth average plus bodied palate, soft carbonation. Okay. Bottle shared by Blankboy

Pour is black with hints of deep brown at the bottom in the light. Nice fluffy khaki head. Aroma is sweet with hints of pine, mint, and herbal note mixing with maybe tropical intermittent dark chocolate or roast/coffee aroma. Taste is pine up front, followed by citrus orange or clementine, rolls into a roast, chocolate pine bitterness to finish. Slight sweetness, nice mellow bitterness. Maybe a touch of alcohol, but probably not. Body is medium to medium full. Nice.

Pours black as night. Thick tan foam last. Smells of prunes and dates. Taste like bitter dark chocolate covered raisins. It has a sweet bourbon like aftertaste with hints of coffee. Nice complex black IPA.
Nice dark IPA. Strong hop notes, but not overpowering. Not a great beer, but a very good one.

22oz bottle - 

Aroma - huge citrusy/grapefruit aroma. Aroma was dominated by the citrus angle hops and it was excellent. 

Appearance - black body, 3-finger dark tan head, above average retention, no noticeable lacing 

Mouthfeel - medium bodied, light carbonation, smooth 

Flavor - light roasted malts, grapefruit bitterness, light sweet coffee flavor, very clean 

Overall - phenomenal for $3.50/bottle. It delivers the hop craving in the aroma, a clean hop foward flavor, supporting malts and while the ABV is high, it drinks like a 5% IPA. Excellent.

BOD 114/14. Pours almost as dark as a stout with an exceptional head, lacing and retention. Nice nose of sweet tropical citrus (orange, pineapple), pine, chocolate/toffee and a touch of roast over a slight alcohol note. Almost light medium bodied with a just a touch of slick texture. Above normal carbonation with a nice effervescent middle and finish. The flavor profile is complex, well balanced and does a stellar job of hiding the alcohol. As the bitterness equilibrates, the coffee/toffee, roast and sweet chocolate come to the forefront in an effervescent flash. The finish is somewhat dry and leaves a nice lingering light bitterness on the tongue with a light toffee and chocolate flavored sweetness coupled with a hint of grapefruit rind tartness.

Growler, Calgary, AB, Canada via Liquor Depot Crowfoot. Jet black, lasting tan head. Great aroma, powerful malt-raisin with black liquorice and prune. Velvety, smooth, molasses sweetness then a bright alcohol infused hop finish.

Bomber poured into a shaker glass. Has a dark black pour, with a light brown head. There was a pine, wood, roasted malt aroma. Nice chocolate, coffee, caramel, and wood roasted malt taste. Overall very satisfying brew.

65cl, at 8.2%Vol, new exclusive American brew Anno 2014, thx alot to Ron for bringing this over!, complex brew, malty/roasted and slightly fruity/bitter/woody, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew
Black with a frothy tan head, lots of lacing. Pine and roasty aroma. Flavor is similar with a little bit of coffee.

Bottle from Bobar: Poured a dark brownish hue almost black with a thick soapy foam head which left behind messy lacing. Aroma was rich with a heavy roasting of malts that also gave off a smoky scent in the background while a notice of spiced up hops play well nicely with the main smells going on. The drink is initially sweet but hits with robust flavors of dark malt.

Bomber purchased at Vons (only $3.59 on sale). Pours black with brown along the edges and two fingers of creamy dark tan foam. AROMA of pine needles, roasted malts, resinous and dank hops, tangerine, and light creamy chocolate. Not as nuanced as some others in the style, but a very quaffable beer. (486, 917)

September 9, 2014 - shared by blankboy with me, jercraigs & mabel. Bomber. Deep clear dark brick red, large slightly diminishing frothy beige head. Deep black with off-white head, taste is a delicious blend of roasted malt and citrus hops. One of the best Black IPAs out there.

Now this is my nectar! Pours an almost opaque black with a nice long lasting brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, grapefruit, pine and resin... Lots going on but balanced nicely. Taste is roasted malts, coffee, citrus hops, grapefruit and pine with a smooth bitterness from got the roast and hops. Nice dry finish as well adds to the complexity of this beer. One of my favorite black ipas to date and how the style should be made... A hopped up American style stout!

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate / cocoa powder), lightly to moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), with a note of alcohol.

Medium to full body, velvety/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic, lightly astringent.

Pretty disappointing. The aroma is plenty assertive, but I cant find much to say about it...roast, chocolate, and west coast hop treatment. Not much else. It pours black with a healthy brown, creamy head that produces a bit of lacing on the side. It has a piney aroma with citrus qualities. It has pop to the citrus flavor that is reminiscent of fresh grapefruit. It also has floral and piney flavors to compliment the citrus pop. It has a bitter bit that compliments the flavors well.

650 ml bottle from Premier Gourmet. Pours a dark brown with orange edges and moderate-sized light tan head that leaves decent lace. Aroma big on dark, roasty notes as well as tropical fruit and floral hops. Flavour is nicely balanced between roast and hops with some cocoa and coffee to go with citrus and floral hops. Alcohol is well hidden. Very nice.
Shared bomber to snifters. Nice roast to balance out the hops. Minimal bitterness on the finish.
Draft - Light roast and big floral hop notes. Deep brown with a rich beige head. Floral and piney with a nice bitterness and only a hint of roast. Great hop character with a light roast.

Black with a dark brown edge. Persistent creamy foam. Big hop aroma. Grassy, pine, and a hint of tobacco. Excellent body. Thick hop flavors and well balanced with the dark malts. Coffee and pine tar play well in the caramel box. Maybe this is a lucky batch or my new favorite. Either way its delicious.

Had on tap at the Grog. $6.50 for the full pint. Pours a mahogany-tinted dark brown with which a beige head 1 finger in length stood. Tastes and smells of juniper berries, blackberries, sawdust, tin, and lemony hops. Wet cardboard, salted caramel, and sourdough experienced by swallow. Fruity, but the complexity only goes so far with this.

22oz bomber. Thick, unfiltered black-brown body. Steady, creamy beige head. Rich, sweet, massive Black IPA...approaching Imperial Stout, but still firmly planted in style with its minty bitter hop bite and sweet specialty malt chocolate and coffee notes. Well done, but I wouldnt go back for another bomber...six pack might be nice.

Sampled May 2014
A steady pour into my New Belgium globe glass produces a two-finger thick, light brown tinged, creamed amber colored head that leaves some nicely layered lacing stuck to the sides as I work my way through this beer. The beer is a concentrated brown color (sort of like a darker chocolate) that shows a clear, concentrated amber / brown hue when held up to the light. Up front the aroma smells of bright hop fruit notes; ripe tangelo zest, kumquat, lots of guava notes, perhaps a touch of mango, sweet floral peach, as well as ample passion fruit. You actually have to focus, and dig around a bit to notice the dark malt, which supplies subtle, toasted whole grain toast notes, a touch of toasted / slightly-roasted hay, and just a touch of burnt dark malt character that almost adds a spiciness to the dominant hop fruit character; this last helps to accentuate notes of pine, as well as a lightly dank herbal character in the hops, though this last seems to add a funky edge to the tropical fruit notes, rather than be notable in-and-of itself.

Up front a bright fruit character is pretty quickly joined by a toasted whole grain dark malt character. The bitterness is fairly smooth and light for a hopped up beer, and actually the light roast character provides a touch of noticeable bitterness. Bright fruit notes of guava, passion fruit, a bit of spicy mango, and sweet ruby-red grapefruit play the dominant role here in the flavor. Roasted notes lightly influence the flavor to, and become dominant in the finish, though cant quite shake loose a bit of lingering fruity and herbal hop character. As the beer warms up the roast character becomes a bit more noticeable; more toasted / roasted whole grain notes, a bit of roasted coffee notes and burnt grain character, as well as a bit more roasted bitterness. The body has a nice, velvety texture to it without being overly heavy; this beer definitely has the quaffability quotient that something labeled an IPA needs, and at 8+% makes for a bit on the dangerous side if you are not paying attention.

The dark malt is really well done here to not overly detract from the hop focus. I am actually pretty impressed with how little a role it plays in the nose, and even in the flavor it only plays a lightly supporting role; the malt adds a spicy & herbal edge to the hop character more than being overly noticeable by itself. Thoroughly enjoyable for the hop heads out there.

At a tasting, many thanks DSG, opaque very dark brown colour, small stable bubbly light brown head, flavour of pine, dark bread and charred notes, flavour of dark chocolate, dark bread, wood and coffee, almost completley dry, mellow medium strong bitterness, exquisitely balanced. Excellent BIPA.

Pours a dark brown with a foamy white head. The brew caters more towards piney citrus notes at the notes with some chocolatelyness. I would more or less compare this style to a black IPA while leaning more towards the IPA. Taste is a little bitter with some sweetness from the malts. Mouth feel is a medium body. Finishes rather long ending mostly in sweet taste and roasted malt aroma.

Pours from bomber a dark brown color with ruby glints at the edges and an off white head. Aroma of citrusy and floral and lightly piney hops, some pale and caramel and dark malts, with light coffee notes. Flavour of tropical fruits, citrus and piney hops mixed with some milk chocolate sweetness. Alcohol well hidden, mouth feel sticky. Very well made.

text: Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks DSG. Pours deep brown-black with a big creamy head. Smell of piney hops, roast and coffee. Sweet with dark chocolate and coffee flavors, medium bitterness, rich and well balanced. Dry and sticky mouthfeel. Very good.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks DSG. Black with tan head. Marmite, olive water, moss and pine with a little dry onion aroma, umami, roasty bitter, inky taste. Smooth, mildly carbonated, full-bodied, dry mouthfeel.

Bomber served in a Duvel glass. The beer pours a near black with a light tan head that covers about 1/2 inch and leaves decent lacing. Aroma is pine, roasted barley, and cocoa. On to tasting. Right off the bat I get a heavy citrus blast mixed with a roasty flavor. Its like dark chocolate and coffee met with piney citrus, with a creamy, yet fairly dry finish. Overall its very satisfying and a great representation of the style.

From a bottle at Mondiale de la Biere 2014, Mulhouse. Dark brown, hazy, medium slightly tanned head. Hoppy smell, notes of pine,blueberry, biscuit and malt with a little sourness. Tastes a bit sweetish with a strong bitterness and hoppy. Notes of chocolate are present. Full body, medium carbonation. Nice!

Serving: Bottle. It pours almost black with a lasting tan head. Strong herbal hop nose with a little dankness and that distinctive Lagunitas aroma. A mix of herbal, pine, black coffee, and heavily roasted malt. Medium to full body. Nice beer.

Bomber into snifter glass, deep dark brown color with tan head. Aroma of citrus/pine hops, roasted malt sweetness, light chocolate and faint nuttiness. Taste adds notes of dark chocolate, light coffee, faint spiciness, dark fruit, liquorice and grapefruity hop bitterness. Medium body, moderate-low carbonation, dry with citrus bitter roasty finish. Well balanced rounded black IPA.

Bottle. Dark chocolate malt and pine/grapefruit peel aroma - very nice hop nose. Dark brown with small head. Sweet molasses/chocolate malt and moderately bitter pine/grapefruit peel flavor. Nice balance. Excellent.

This has a nice, sweet, malty aroma with a little ice cream sundae in there. The taste is drier and more acidic than expected - strong, but not especially good. The flavors of espresso, drying hops, cigars, and grapefruit peel become a bit nasty. It was a little too much for my palate, sorry to say.
Dark brown with thick head. Piney hops has a big aroma presence. Charred taste with a hoppy after taste. Does not taste too heavy. Good beer
A smooth, big, malty Black IPA. Brings together a solid hoppy feel with the roasted chocolate notes. Really well made. A typically robust yet easy drinking beer from Lagunitas.

A black ipa is a surprisingly hard style to do in my mind. When it is done right though it is a pretty entertaining drink. You have to get the bitterness of the roasty malt matched with the bitterness of your hop profile. Sort of like mixing two records together. This one gets it pretty damn well. Pine and smooth citrus flavors. Mixing in with the bittersweet malt and light roastiness tasty.

9/17/2014. 22 oz. bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Nice lacing. Roasted malt, chocolate, pine, citrus. Typical over the top West Coast style (in a good way) with loads of hop bitterness. Some sweet notes there too. Long bitter finish.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Ariels place. Black with a beige to light brown head. Aroma of roast and "green" and piney hops. Flavor with roast, dark chocolate, piney and a bit fruity hops and a bitter finish. Rounded mouthfeel. A very nice Black IPA.

Bottle from CBB shared at the Summer Plunder Tasting. A dark black pour with a big juicy citrus aroma - wonderful. Very soft chocolatey citrus chewy malt body. Really good stuff, a well made black IPA that finds the right balance between the malt and the hops.
Very good drinkability as balanced. Would like a bit more hoppy, maybe if it was in first weeks. Fresh From Premier Gourmet.

NightTime. Has a brew name ever been so simple, so memorable, or so perfectly suited to its style as the one on this Black IPA? I think not. NightTime pours black. No question about that. The head is phenomenal - dark brown with great retention. Roasted malt and citrusy hop aroma. Flavors in Black IPAs are often extremely complex but this one takes it to another level. Dark fruit flavors (plumb and prune with subtler notes of grape and raspberry), citrusy fruit flavors (grapefruit, pinapple, and orange peel), spicy flavors (pepper, mostly), toasted malt flavors (chocolate, coffee, caramel), and sweet boozy flavors (a candy-like sweetness; some reviews say its like black licorice - thats pretty close). This is one of the best beers Lagunitas has put out in a while, and Lagunitas makes some fine brews.

Pours very dark with khaki colored head. Very nice balance of malts and hops. Very enjoyable dark IPA.

Bottle.

A- Citrus, spices, hoppy, cocoa.

A- Black color, dark liquid, tan bubbly head.

T- Citrus, spices, bitter, pepper.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, smooth finish.

O- One of the better black IPAs I have had. Not my favorite style, but this brew was balanced and complex.

Aroma is malt, pine, raisin and grapefruit. 22 pours black like coffee with a creamy off white head and curtain lacing. Taste has licorice, dark malts, grapefruit and chocolate. Mouthfeel is active with a well balanced finish that has grassy citrus and roasted malt notes.
Leafy greens mixed with dark roasty malts. Not quite as good as the B space invaders but it s good- Lagunitas good.

Enjoyed on draft at World of Beer Gilbert, in a snifter glass, outside on a temperate Arizona night. This is a great, well-balanced black IPA, thick, flavorful, with aroma to match. Roasted malts meet a core of hops.

650 mL bottle. Not quite stout dark, with a small, light-brown head. Laces nicely. The very appealing aroma is dominated by chocolate, with berries, citrus, and spice. The flavour is not as bold as the aroma, but it is tasty and incredibly drinkable. This double black IPA is heavier on the malt, and lighter on the hops than many of its peers, but in this case, not only does it work, but it helps NightTime to stand out in a crowd.

Bomber:
Pours black with a few barely purple lights...and a Huge, frothy, rough bubbled, lacy light brown head.
Grapefruit, pine, chocolate aroma.
Flavour is cream...rich chocolate malt/fudge, pine and peel bitter.
Wow....incredibly creamy and smooth.
A tiny bit of warmth from the alcohol.
This is an outstanding BIPA....delicious........awesome.

One of the best black IPAs Ive had yet. The roasted malt adds a little sweetness and fills out the body, giving it a level of balance that isnt usually seen in standard IPAs. I was surprised to see that this is 8.6%, it didnt seem that strong.

Poured from 1 pint 6 fl oz bottle. Brownish black with beige head. Aroma of hops and mild roast malt. Tastes comes out with a little more roast malt and sweetness. Still a mild roast overall with a nice light resinous hop profile.

Bottle from Joes. Near black with lasting dense tan head and lace. Pungent citrus aroma with hints of roasted coffee wood earth and wet leaves. Medium roasted mild chocolate coffee and raisin with nice citrus rind and mocha dry finish. Medium body, light for abv. Actually tastes more like and IPA than a hoppy porter. Probably the best black IPA Ive had. Fuck yeah.

Split this bottle with my dad this weekend. The pour into the pint glass is dark and mysterious with a frothy tan head. Smells of obvious hops with roasty malt and sugars. Taste is sweet at first and then smacks you with hop bite, fruits and piney resin overcome the sticky finish. A lovely BIPA indeed. Thanks Lagunitas!
22oz bottle. Poured a black color with a tan head. Pine, floral hops, roasty, and citrus.

All beers containing Summit hops should bear a warning label. WARNING SUMMIT HOPS. Dark pour, some kind of head, blah blah blah. Garlicky, onion like hops over a sweet chocolate base. The sweetness and bitterness were well balanced, but they chose summit hops. Yuck.

Pours dark brown with a thick light tan head. Aroma is heavy pine and roasted malts. Taste is initially the piney hops followed very quickly by rich rich malts and light syrup. That is followed by a substantially malty finish - the hop bitterness takes a back seat. This black IPA is very well done. Awesome!

Black with a thick off white head. Aroma is roasted malt with a touch of citrus from the hops. Flavor is bitter hops followed by a strong roasted malt. Hops come out more as it warms (or with spicy food). Very well balanced black IPA, not as muddy as some. Finish is bitter and a bit dry with a tiny bit of sweetness.

Wife: 4

Dark brown pour with a small tan head. Nice lacing. The aroma is burnt bakers chocolate and resinous, piney, tangerine hops. The flavor goes from sweet, to fruity to roasty, then finishes bitter. Fairly well balanced, with some residual sweetness keep this from being too astringent or bitter.

Bomber bottle: Pours midnight black. More black malts than hops on the nose. Chocolate, toffee, roasted aroma. This is a black IPA which I am not a big fan of the style. But this is a very pleasant beer with balance. Overall, it hides its 8.6% ABV very well and has a refreshing, bittering finish.

Draught at Bruekelen Bier Merchants. Pours with a nice head and some lace. Aroma is sweet beautifully west coast hopped with really well integrated roast. Flavor is the same. Feel is fairly lively with bitter mouth watering and roast taking over. Really love this BIPA. might by redeeming the style.

Decent tan head. Has a good hoppy/malty aroma typical of black IPAs but with an almost sour/roasty note (but not in a bad way). The same comes through in the taste. Pretty good black IPA.

ours black with a brown head and aroma of sweet hops, citrus, and tropical fruits. Taste is bitter, hops, citrus, and tropical fruits with roasted malt and burnt notes underlying leading into the slight bitter, dry, roasty smooth finish. Great black IPA
Pours a dark black brown color with a small canvas head. Notes of chocolate, vinegar, dirt, brownie, citrus, and fresh air. Nice balanced mouthfeel.

Pours a very brownish black color with a thin head. Aromia is hops, grapefruit, floral, small pine, burning rubber. Taste is espresso, coffee beans, dark chocolate, citrus. Overall a very bitter but drinkable beer, not as malty as most of the style.

bottle. near black with two finger head. im some what over the black ipa trend, but this is outstanding. rather light body for the style. definitely a malty ipa rather than a hoppy stout. awesome hops.

A black body with a tan head that had great lace and retention. Aroma was of roasted malts and mostly grapefruit hops there was enough pine hops and a bit of mango. Flavor had mostly grapefruit hops. Roasted malts seem restrained and the pine hops provided enough balance. Easy to drink.

22 oz. bottle from Root Cellar. Pours an opaque brown with a finger of khaki head that leaves heavy lace in the glass. Notes of dark chocolate, citrus fruits (orange peel, mostly), earth, tobacco, toast, cocoa powder, dark fruits, and leaves. Light-medium bodied, with low to moderate carbonation and a roasty, chalky mouthfeel. Earthy black IPA. Drinks nicely.
Pretty much black, bright off white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, chocolate. Taste is cocoa, bitter pine. Delicious.

Bomber. Pours near black with a chalky brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has lots of musty dark grains with light roast and an earthy pine backbone. Flavor begins with a pine and dark grain combination and finishes with a bit of roasted malt.
From a bottle. Pours black with a huge beige head. Aromas of floral hops and hay. Flavors are floral hops, cocoa, dark fruits, nuttiness, bready tones. Delicious!

On tap. Dark brown murky pour with small beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, grapefruit, pine, hops and faint caramel. Taste of caramel, roasted malts, slight fruits, pine, hops and grapefruit. Full bodied, medium carbonation, long sticky hop finish. Something not quite right with this one.

Aroma - deep tropical notes, with a hint of coffee.

Appearance - Typical Lagunitas beer - very great looking.

Taste - Very crisp. Very smooth with a nice smooth aftertaste.

Palate - great lingering taste

Overall - very good black ale.

Taste is dominated by a roasty, almost smoky malt of dark chocolate and coffee. Hop flavor is there, but overpowered by the malt, leaving a pine resin flavor. Mouthfeel is medium with a low to moderate combination and a slight astringency. Finishes with a lingering roasted chocolate malt on the tongue.

Full bodied and smooth. A bit messy though and although its a good beer in its style, I prefer regular (I)IPAs.

This beer is black with a large, pillowy light brown head, and the aroma blends resin and floral hops with roasted malts. The taste doesnt initially hit you as many black IPAs do because the slight umami doesnt overwhelm the mild bitterness and slight sourness from the hops; however, the malty bitterness does come through more in the finish as the hop flavor fades slightly. The palate rounds this beer out nicely with the slick texture, medium body, and a soft carbonation.

Look: pours a dark brown. Light tan head. Thick lacing.
Smell: very hop forward. Pine. Citrus. Very bitter. Dark roasted maltiness.
Taste: dark roasted malts. Slight pine. Grapefruit. Lemon. Tangerine. 
Feel: very dry. Leaves a thin film on the mouth. Medium carbonation.
Overall: great black IPA. Very hop forward. Love the way there is a slight maltiness to it. A little more balanced than a normal IPA. 
First drank: home 8/21/14

A solid VERY aromatic black IPA. The nose is fantastic (9.5)...as hoppy as hop stoopid with just enough dark malts to balance and make more complex. your nose will continually wander back to the glass or bottle. Feel is a little lighter than expected, as is the flavor (given the aroma) but this is solid across the board and one of their best. A very nice addition to the black ipa family :

22 oz bottle from Whole Foods, Dublin, OH, for $5.99, into 16 oz tumbler. Super dark near-black garnet brown; massive, ridiculous, creamy, white brown head; huge amounts of lacing left behind by a quarter-inch layer of head thats still in place with less than 2 oz of liquid in the glass--insane. Deep, sweet, dark aroma, yet bright citrus underlies the whole thing; caramel, brown sugar, toffee, with floral notes. Lots of light, silky carbonation. Medium-full mouthfeel; medium sticky yet oily and slick. This would rank very, very highly for me if I were more a fan of the style.
Poured from a bomber into a Lagunitas pint glass a darkest brown black with a tan head.Aroma is roasty citurs Flavor is grapefruit, cocoa, bitter finish. Settles well on the tongue.

On tap at Brass Tap, Pembrook Pines with Z, pours a pitch black color with a nice java head. Nose is deep citrus, with a predominance of passion fruit , very fragrant. Taste is citrus, with a predominance of mostly grapefruit with some resin and pine. Finish is again citrusy with a long lingering bitter sweet finish. Great BIPA. Quaff Score 8 / 10

On tap at Brass Tap Pembroke Pines. Pours black with a brown head and aroma of sweet hops, citrus, and tropical fruits. Taste is bitter, hops, citrus, and tropical fruits with roasted malt and burnt notes underlying leading into the slight bitter, dry, roasty smooth finish. Great black IPA

On tap...the pour is black silk and the mouthfeel follows - incredibly smooth - my mouth was overjoyed with this substance in it. Very complex with lots of subtle flavors making themselves known and yet all in harmony. May all beers aspire to be this good.

text:
Visual: Pours dark cola brown with a smallish but super long lasting top-foamy/bottom bubbly head, a wall of super sticky lacing, a meteor shower of CO2 activity.

Nose: lively grapefruit citrus hops despite its stout-like appearance (lvl-6)-pungency

Attack: incoming hops

Mid-palate: immediate pineapple, ultra bright (lvl-6)-sweetness, fizzy, (MAIN) soft caramel malts, resin, *hint* chocolate

Finish: sweet malts + sharp pine/grapefruit hopped bitterness, a touch of roast.

Summary: A heroic balance of bitter hopped character, bright fruitiness, dark malts and gentle sweetness. Full-bodied and very drinkable, all for a great price.

Bottle. Pours black with a foamy tan head. Brilliant C-hop aroma with a hint of roasted grains. Taste is well-balanced; starts off sweet with citrus fruits, moves into licorice, roasty notes, and a bitter finish creeps up. Silky smooth body. Very nice.

Pours thin black with a small white top. Aroma is light citrus hop, light roasted malts. Taste is more of a dark lager, light roast malts and nice earthy malts with a light pine hop but pales in comparison to the other Lagunitas offerings.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2015 Bottle. Black. Aroma is coco, and pine. Taste adds big earthy dark robust hops, coffee, and sugar. Easy mouthfeel, hop bitterness on the finish. Light for the style. Smooth with a nice bite. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark cola with a white head. Aroma is melon, caramel and tangerine. Taste adds some chocolate malt. Medium sticky mouthfeel and light carb. Solid.

Draft. Pours a clear dark red-brown with a thin creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of citrus and tropical hops, roasted malts and chocolate. The taste is roasted malts, chocolate, citrus and tropical hops. Medium bodied, slight lingering bitterness.

Smoked malt aroma has a strong overtone of woody hops and a hint of molasses. Hops dominate the flavor, woody but scarcely bitter, with hints of green wood; smoky malt, molasses and licorice make their appearances as well.

Rye, wood and sugars hold the middle, while the ends turns more bitter and hoppy with lemon, orange pith, grapefruit and grasses. Lingers for a short period on the sides of the mouth.
